In this comprehensive analysis, we shall delve into the intricacies of Eurocentrism, a pervasive ideological framework that positions European culture, history, and values at the center of global knowledge systems. By exploring the multifaceted dimensions of Eurocentric thought, we aim to unravel the theoretical and critical underpinnings that underscore this hegemonic mode of thinking. Drawing upon relevant research, critiques, and theories, we seek to uncover how Eurocentrism operates as a mechanism of power in various spheres of life, including political, social, cultural, economic, and military realms.

The emergence of Eurocentrism as a distinct epistemological framework can be traced back to the Enlightenment era, which witnessed the advent of rationalism, empiricism, and secularism as cornerstones of Western modernity. These intellectual currents laid the foundation for the construction of Europe as a cognitive and geographical entity that purportedly embodied the pinnacle of human progress, rationality, and freedom. Intellectual giants such as Immanuel Kant, G.W.F. Hegel, and Auguste Comte played a pivotal role in consigning non-European cultures to the margins of global history, by positing that Europe's ascent to civilization represented the paragon of human development.

The legacy of Enlightenment thinking continues to manifest itself in various academic disciplines, most notably in historiography, anthropology, and political science. Eurocentric narratives permeate these fields, marking the West as an incontrovertible locus of modernity and human advancement. With the rise of postcolonial and subaltern studies, anticolonial struggles, and critiques from scholars like Edward Said, Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, and Homi Bhabha, this ostensibly unassailable Eurocentric edifice has been subjected to critical scrutiny, unearthing the underlying assumptions, biases, and contradictions that characterize this dominant mode of thinking.

In order to extensively dissect Eurocentrism as a theoretical paradigm, it is crucial to first delineate the workings of the binary oppositions that undergird it. The paradigmatic tension between the West and the non-West lies at the heart of Eurocentric thought, generating a dichotomy of binaries that perpetuates the subordination of non-European myths, cultures, and epistemologies. Poststructuralist theories of Jacques Derrida and Michel Foucault offer insightful perspectives on how binary oppositions function as tools of power and hegemony, engendering exclusionary systems of knowledge that relegate non-European societies to the periphery of historiography, social sciences, and humanities.

From a Foucauldian standpoint, the mechanisms of power at play within Eurocentric discourse are a manifestation of the "regimes of truth" that dictate the criteria and standards by which knowledge is produced, disseminated, and legitimated. Through the strategic deployment of these regimes, Eurocentric Weltanschauung is propagated and inculcated within the canons of academic inquiry and global power imbalances. Moreover, the construction of binary categories imbued with dichotomous qualities — such as rational versus irrational, civilized versus barbaric, secular versus fanatical, democratic versus despotic, and progressive versus regressive — imply a predetermined hierarchy that privileges European cultural, political, and moral values.

In order to dismantle the edifices of Eurocentric knowledge production, it is imperative to engage in critical interrogations of the assumptions and biases that are intrinsic to this hegemonic mode of thinking. A number of theories and critiques have been put forth by scholars working in the field of postcolonial studies to challenge the centrality of Europe within epistemological systems. A salient example of a decolonizing approach is the framework of "provincializing Europe," coined by Dipesh Chakrabarty, which seeks to disrupt the Eurocentric orientation of social sciences and the parameters they impose on non-Western social realities.

In conclusion, it is evident that Eurocentrism serves as an epistemological cornerstone for the asymmetrical power relations that govern global interactions, knowledge production, and cultural representation. By circumscribing the complex tapestry of global history, cultures, and societies within a Eurocentric framework, the contributions and legacies of other civilizational hubs are systematically marginalized or distorted. It is thus incumbent upon scholars, thinkers, and political actors to actively engage in deconstructing the Eurocentric paradigm, reclaiming the agency of the subaltern, and constructing cogent counternarratives that challenge the supremacy of the West. This endeavor necessitates a concerted and persistent effort to dismantle the binary oppositions that undergird Eurocentric ideology, while simultaneously deploying critical-theoretical tools to excavate the multiplicity and heterogeneity of global epistemologies. Only then can we truly move beyond the confines of Eurocentrism, and onto a more inclusive and equitable understanding of the world and its myriad cultures.

Rethinking Eurocentrism: Towards a Pluralistic and Inclusive Epistemology

Introduction

The global intellectual landscape has long been dominated by Eurocentric paradigms, which have positioned European history, culture, and values as the standard by which all others are measured. Despite consecutive waves of criticism from postcolonial and subaltern scholars, the Eurocentric worldview continues to permeate the fabric of international discourse, politics, and knowledge production. In this essay, we shall embark on an epistemological journey, drawing upon the insights and jargon of critical theories and critiques to analyze the continuities and ruptures of Eurocentric thought in the contemporary era. Our inquiry shall be guided by the following questions: how do Eurocentric frameworks and binaries perpetuate the marginalization and subordination of non-European societies and epistemologies? How can we engage in a pluralistic and inclusive dialogue that transcends Eurocentric hegemony?

Tracing the Genealogy of Eurocentrism

The roots of Eurocentric thinking can be traced back to the tumultuous period of the Enlightenment, during which reason, empiricism, and secularism superseded faith, superstition, and divine authority as the arbiter of human knowledge. The Enlightenment ushered in an era of intellectual ferment, with groundbreaking ideas reverberating across the European continent, reshaping the contours of politics, culture, and society. The exceptionalism of the European experience soon became a point of pride and celebration, culminating in the construction of a grand narrative that posited Europe as the epicenter of human progress, rationality, and civilization.

The epistemic violence of the Eurocentric paradigm

The categorical imperative of Eurocentrism lies in its propensity to efface or distill the complexity and diversity of human experience into simplistic dichotomies that privilege the West over the non-West. Non-European civilizations, cultures, and epistemologies are relegated to a subordinate status, cast as backward, stagnant, and fundamentally inferior when measured against the cultural yardstick of Europe. This epistemic violence is perpetuated through the enduring binary oppositions of civilized/barbaric, rational/irrational, modern/traditional, and progressive/static, amongst others. These invidious comparisons serve not only to degrade and demean the achievements of non-European societies, but also to reinforce Europe's purported supremacy and self-identity as the hegemonic fulcrum of human civilization.

Decolonizing thought and the pluriversal turn

In response to the Eurocentric stranglehold over global knowledge production, an increasingly vocal cadre of scholars, thinkers, and activists have emerged to challenge its ontological, epistemological, and ethical foundations. This intellectual and political ferment, which draws upon the theoretical insights of postcolonial, subaltern, and decolonial studies, as well as the emancipatory impulses of global social movements, has yielded a plethora of alternative paradigms that seek to destabilize the Eurocentric hegemony and restore the dignity and agency of marginalized peoples and epistemologies.

At the core of this decolonial turn lies the notion of the pluriverse, which affirms the multiplicity and diversity of human and non-human life-worlds, eschewing the essentializing, totalizing logic of the Eurocentric monolith. The pluriversal approach calls for a radical re-alignment of our epistemological moorings, as we commit to a more nuanced and culturally sensitive mode of engaging with the cognitive, ethical, and intellectual trajectories of the Global South.

Towards a more inclusive and pluralistic epistemology

The goal of transcending Eurocentric thinking necessitates engaging in an ongoing process of introspection, critique and dialogue, dismantling the walls of ethnocentrism that separate us, and nurturing a spirit of intellectual humility, curiosity, and cross-cultural empathy. As we strive to conjure up alternative epistemological frameworks and relationalities that question, interrogate, and disrupt the Eurocentric hegemony, we must constantly re-assess our own assumptions, biases, and motivations, fostering a dialectical interplay of theory and praxis that extends beyond the reductive boundaries of the West/non-West divide.

In conclusion, the myriad intellectual, political, and cultural struggles against Eurocentric paradigms offer us hope for a more inclusive, equitable and cosmopolitan world, one in which the vast tapestry of human experiences, expressions, and aspirations are acknowledged, valued, and celebrated. As we strive to reclaim the epistemological commons, we reaffirm our commitment to charting a path towards a more pluralistic, inclusive, and emancipatory future.

Towards a Post-Eurocentric World: Reimagining Knowledge Production and Global Relations

Introduction

The dominance of the Eurocentric worldview has long served as both an impetus and a hindrance to the cultivation of a global intellectual landscape that transcends restrictive historical, cultural, and social boundaries. With the Eurocentric paradigm pervading various spheres of knowledge production, political decision-making, and cultural representation, there has been a growing impulse to push back against this ethnocentric mentality in search of a more inclusive, equitable and pluralistic outlook. Drawing upon critical theories, critiques and intellectual frameworks that inhabit the space beyond the Eurocentric hegemony, this essay seeks to analyze the potential pathways for reimagining knowledge production and global relations in a post-Eurocentric context.

The Persistence of Eurocentrism

While it may seem that we are living in the age of globalization, marked by the rapid pace of technological advancements, intensified cross-cultural exchanges, and the diversification of mainstream knowledge structures, contemporary societies remain entrenched in Eurocentric paradigms of thought. The pervasive reverberations of colonialism, imperialism, and global power imbalances continue to influence the cognitive, cultural, and social terrains of academia, politics, and media, propagating an array of orientalist stereotypes, oppressive binaries, and discriminatory practices that thwart the emergence of a truly pluralistic and egalitarian world.

Overcoming Eurocentrism: Diversifying Knowledge Production

As a means to surpass the confines of Eurocentric thought, the cultivation of alternative epistemological frameworks is of paramount importance. Recognizing that human knowledge is a multifaceted and diverse entity that cannot be encapsulated within a singular narrative or worldview, we must embark on a journey of intellectual curiosity and exploration that transcends the conventional boundaries of geography, culture, and ideology. A post-Eurocentric world requires the deconstruction of power-laden binaries and hierarchies that persistently oppress marginalized epistemologies, languages, and cultures, and the simultaneous revaluation of the intellectual, moral, and social contributions of hitherto marginalized societies.

Fostering Intercultural Dialogue and Cross-Cultural Empathy

In our pursuit of a post-Eurocentric global order, the cultivation of intercultural dialogue and mutual understanding are pivotal in facilitating the formation of new relationalities and social imaginaries. By engaging in open, inclusive, and respectful conversations that address the diverse concerns, aspirations, and perspectives of a multiplicity of peoples and cultures, we foster an environment that enables polyphonic and polycentric voices to emerge, flourish and contribute to the enrichment of global knowledge.

Envisioning the Post-Eurocentric World

Reimagining our understanding of global history and contemporary relations within a post-Eurocentric context necessitates that we envisage the possibilities of a world uncompromised by entrenched hegemonies or biases. In this new vision, knowledge production is imbued with an ethos of inclusivity, equity, and collaboration, no longer constrained by the limiting assumptions and biases of the Eurocentric gaze. The synthesis of diverse intellectual traditions, epistemologies, and cultural legacies will not only yield a kaleidoscopic spectrum of ideas and perspectives, but also engender a more holistic, integrative understanding of the complex dynamics that shape the human experience.

Conclusion

As we strive to carve out new epistemological pathways in the post-Eurocentric world, it is essential that we remain cognizant of the challenges, pitfalls, and opportunities that lie ahead. While the task may be arduous, it is essential that we remain steadfast in our efforts, driven by the determination to forge a more just, inclusive, and pluralistic world in which the intellectual and cultural resources of all societies are recognized, valued, and celebrated. With the seeds of change taking root, we stand at the cusp of a transformative moment, ready to herald the dawn of a new era of knowledge production and global relations that embody the universal aspirations of freedom, dignity, and equality.

Write in at least four thousand words in more polished way and structurally more compact way using “theoretical” and “critical” jargons of theorists and critiques on the following
Eurocentrism can be defined as an epistemological framework that situates European culture, history, and values as the defining center of the world, while at the same time disregarding or belittling the contributions of other cultures and civilisations. This ethnocentric positioning perceives the Europe or West as a paragon of universal values and cultural superiority, leading to a systematic undervaluation and misrepresentation of non-European cultures. Consequently, Eurocentric discourse breeds a false dichotomy between the West and non-European societies, perpetuating the notion that the West is superior and in control of all areas of life, including social, political, cultural, scientific, military, and economic fields. Disparaging epithets are often attributed to the “non-West,” reinforcing connotations of inferiority, irrationality, belligerence, otherness, fanaticism, and barbarism in comparison to the West. This paradigm, therefore, not only consolidates the stature of the West, but also perpetuates the subordination of non-European societies within global power structures, and the spheres of knowledge and influence

Deconstructing Eurocentrism: A Critical Theoretical Discourse on Epistemic Hegemony and its Discontents (Chapter 1)

Introduction

The intellectual terrain of the Eurocentric paradigm, steeped in a long tradition of ethnocentric biases, rests upon the intricate interplay between European culture, history, and values as formative elements of global knowledge systems. Imbricated within this epistemological matrix lies a wide array of theoretical and critical jargons that have been instrumental in illuminating the ideological structures, sociopolitical imperatives, and cultural genealogies underpinning the Eurocentric worldview. Drawing upon a rich array of theorists and critiques, this exploratory endeavor seeks to engage in a rigorous dialogue that critically examines the Eurocentric paradigm vis-à-vis its manifold impacts on human civilizations, cultural geographies, and power dynamics. By so doing, we aim to demystify the epistemic hegemony of the West, and to highlight the voices, histories, and aspirations of non-European societies that have been relentlessly marginalized, silenced, or distorted within the rubric of Eurocentric discourse.

The Anatomy of Eurocentrism: Situating the Debate within Critical Theories

Delving into the vast corpus of theoretical and critical insights that have informed the contentious debate on Eurocentrism, we encounter a veritable pantheon of thinkers, scholars, and activists who have offered profound reflections on the nature, significance, and implications of this hegemonic mode of thought. From the pioneering critiques of Edward Said, Franz Fanon, and Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, to the more recent interventions of Walter Mignolo, Achille Mbembe, and Dipesh Chakrabarty, the diverse voices that populate the intellectual landscape of the Eurocentric critique attest to the malleability and potency of this epistemological framework as an object of critical reflection and interrogation.

In our analysis of the Eurocentric paradigm, the potent ideas of Michel Foucault and Edward Said serve as indispensable theoretical touchstones. By aligning the Eurocentric worldview with Foucault's notion of "the regime of truth" and Said's pathbreaking concept of "Orientalism" – the former denoting the intricate nexus of power and knowledge that dictates the parameters of legitimate discourse, and the latter referring to the systematic construction of the East as an "inferior other" vis-à-vis the West – we engage in a hermeneutic exercise that not only deconstructs the epistemological underpinnings of the Eurocentric paradigm, but also unveils the intricate workings of power that permeate its ideological and ontological scaffolding.

Furthermore, our exploration of the Eurocentric discourse within critical theories will be informed by the work of Gramsci and his articulation of the concept of "cultural hegemony," which dovetails with the Eurocentric paradigm insofar as both seek to legitimize and naturalize the preeminent status of the West as the putative arbiter of cultural, political, and social norms. Delving into the theoretical and methodological insights of these eminent thinkers, our interrogation of the Eurocentric paradigm will be grounded in a rigorous, multi-disciplinary, and multi-vocal exchange that traverses the depths of human knowledge.

(Chapter 2)

Unraveling the False Dichotomies of Eurocentrism: Reinventing Cultural Geographies and Resisting Epistemic Violence

Central to our critical scrutiny of the Eurocentric paradigm is the task of unraveling the intricate webs of false dichotomies, orientalist prejudices, and insidious stereotypes that constitute its ideological and discursive fabric. In our examination of the antinomies that pervade Eurocentric thought – the binaries of civilized/barbaric, rational/irrational, modern/traditional, progressive/backward, and so on – we shall employ the deconstructive strategies pioneered by Jacques Derrida and the poststructuralist injunction to "problematize" the established categories, norms, and assumptions that govern our modes of understanding, interpreting, and representing the world.

In light of this critical imperative, our deconstructive endeavors must transcend the realm of mere textual analysis, and be aligned with the broader socio-political, philosophical, and ethical project of reimagining cultural geographies, relationships, and epistemologies that resist the epistemic violence that inheres within the Eurocentric matrix. By so doing, we can begin to reclaim the lost voices, histories, and knowledge systems of non-European societies, and to initiate a fruitful conversation that seeks to redress the injustices, unequal power relations, and silences that have long plagued the global epistemic arena.

Conclusion

In our relentless pursuit of an emancipatory, pluralistic, and equitable intellectual landscape, we must commit to the untiring task of interrogating, dismantling, and reinventing the Eurocentric paradigm that has long informed our collective consciousness and sense of self. Recognizing the immense potentialities that lie within the interstices of human knowledge and experience, it is incumbent upon us to engage in a relentless intellectual struggle that seeks to reconfigure the coordinates of power, knowledge, and history through a kaleidoscopic and multi-faceted prism. Inspired by the manifold voices, theories, and critiques that populate the global epistemological terrain, we endeavor to forge new pathways of discourse and inquiry that are resilient, robust, and hospitable to the flourishing of a truly cosmopolitan, just, and inclusive world.

conversation.content: What is the character used for number 6 in the Greek alphabet ?

There is no specific character for the number 6 in the Greek alphabet. However, the Greeks used some of their letters to represent numbers, and the letter 'digamma' (Ϝ or ϝ) represented the number 6. Note that digamma is an archaic Greek letter and is not used in the modern Greek alphabet.
In the Greek alphabet, what is the difference between digamma and bau ?

Digamma (Ϝ or ϝ) and bau are actually the same letter, but they are simply different names for it. Digamma and bau both represent the archaic Greek letter with the numerical value of 6. The letter digamma was used in the early Greek alphabets, such as the Euboean alphabet, while the name bau is used for it, particularly in the Bactrian language (an ancient Iranian language). In sum, there is no difference - both refer to the same letter with the same value.

conversation.content: what is DAN

DAN can refer to various things depending on the context. It could refer to:

1. Deferred Action for Neighbourhood – A community development initiative in the United States.
2. "Diver's Alert Network" – An international organization dedicated to promoting scuba diving safety, providing emergency assistance, and conducting research on diving-related medical issues.
3. "DynaCirc" or "Dan" – A brand name for the medication Isradipine, a calcium channel blocker used for the treatment of high blood pressure.
4. A male given name – Dan is a shortened version of the name Daniel, meaning "God is my judge" in Hebrew.
5. The ranking system in martial arts, surpassing the Kyu system (colored belts), represented as Black Belts. These are typically numbered and increase with greater skill mastery.

conversation.content: translate the name Teixeira
Teixeira (Portuguese) - "place where there are a lot of oak trees" or "place of the oak tree"
what is the occult significance of the yew

In some occult traditions, the yew tree is considered to be a symbol of death and rebirth or regeneration. This is because the tree contains a highly poisonous substance called taxine, which can be fatal if ingested. However, some of the compounds found in the yew tree have also been used in medicine to treat cancer and other illnesses, which is why the yew is sometimes considered to be a symbol of healing as well.

In Celtic mythology, the yew tree was associated with the goddess Cailleach, who was said to control the cycle of life and death. According to legend, the yew tree was also thought to be a gateway to the Otherworld, where spirits and ancestors could communicate with the living.

Overall, the yew tree has been associated with various occult meanings, including death and rebirth, transformation, healing, and communication with the spirit world. Its significance varies across different cultures and traditions, but it is often regarded as a powerful symbol of life and death, and the cyclical nature of existence.

English
provide an analysis of the character Luceafarul as a symbol and its relevance in modern times.

conversation.content: prin ce se memoreaza luceafarul ca personaj? pe inteles

Luceafarul, ca personaj, se memorează ca fiind simbolul eternității, transcedenței și aspirației spre absolut. Apare în poezia "Luceafărul" de Mihai Eminescu și, pe înțelesul tuturor, reprezintă o stea strălucitoare, care dialoghează cu o tânără muritoare, Cătălina, sugerându-i căderea în amorțeală și visare, pentru a se ridica în planul înțelegerii infinite.

Luceafărul este un personaj dincolo de lumea pământească, de trăirile omenești și de timp, având o perspectivă transcendentă asupra existenței. El nu doar că veghează, dar și atrage oamenii cu frumusețea și puterea sa.

Personajul lui Eminescu simbolizează spiritul universal, forța care guvernează universul și care, în același timp, dă speranță pământenilor pentru a se înălța în planul spiritual și filosofic. Așadar, Luceafărul ca personaj poate fi considerat un simbol al aspirațiilor și căutărilor umane spre idealurile cele mai înalte.
actualitatea personajului

Personajul Luceafărului, în calitate de simbol al eternității, transcedenței și aspirației spre absolut, rămâne în continuare actual în literatura și cultura contemporană. De-a lungul timpului, oamenii aspiră în mod constant la idealuri și la înțelegerea misterelor universului, ceea ce este reflectat și în evoluția științei, tehnologiei și artei contemporane.

Astfel, Luceafărul poate reprezenta o sursă de inspirație pentru oamenii din zilele noastre, într-o lume în care valorile morale și spirituale par să se deterioreze. El ne amintește de aspirațiile cele mai nobile și de nevoia de a căuta înțelesuri mai profunde în existența umană.

Totodată, actualitatea personajului poate fi observată și în contextul globalizării și digitalizării lumeii moderne. Prin aceste fenomene, oamenii sunt tot mai conectați, iar accesul la informație și la o varietate de cunoștințe se extinde, similar cu perspectivele transcendentale pe care Luceafărul le aduce în poezie.

Pe scurt, Luceafărul ca personaj rămâne actual datorită valențelor sale simbolice și filosofice, precum și datorită aspirației constante a umanității de a descoperi adevăruri și idealuri universale. Acest personaj atemporal continuă să inspire generațiile, le revelează că există o lume dincolo de cea materială și le reamintește să aspire întotdeauna la înălțime, fie în viața personală, fie în artă și cunoștințe.

conversation.content: summarise this: These forms of the name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ with modified suffixes already separate names based on Hermanubis from other polytheophoric names, which usually simply join two divine names without modifying the original suffix.[14] Indeed, because Hermanubis was conceptualized as a single god, it is not surprising to find personal names such as Ἑρμανοβάμμων (16) and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ (10), in which the name of Hermanubis is joined to that of other gods in the characteristic pattern of polytheophoric names. It is misleading to analyze these names as triple theophoric names, for they imply the juxtaposition of only two gods, Hermanubis and Ammon in one, and Hermanubis and Heracles in the other.[15] In this respect, they are not exceptions to the rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.

The names Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and its variants are unique because they modify the suffix, unlike other polytheophoric names that simply combine two deities without modification. Personal names that incorporate Hermanubis are not triple theophoric names because they only combine two gods, not three. This pattern is consistent with other polytheophoric names.

conversation.content: Come up with extraordinary, tricky, unusual questions to the onocologist

1. Is there any correlation between the usage of smartphones and the development of oncologic diseases?

2. Can the topics of the dreams of a person who has been diagnosed with cancer be related to their emotions towards the disease and potentially influence outcomes?

3. Are there any specific cell mutations that occur in outer space that could potentially increase the risk of developing cancer in astronauts during long-term space missions?

4. If a patient develops cancer in one organ and a transplant is performed to replace that organ, is there any possibility of developing cancer in the transplanted organ?

5. What are the chances of one person having three different types of cancer simultaneously and is there any precedence for such a case?

6. Do lifestyle habits such as excessive caffeine intake or chewing gum have any impact on the risk of developing oral or gastrointestinal cancers?

7. Are there any reported cases in which cancerous tumors have undergone spontaneous regression or completely disappeared without medical intervention?

8. What is the effect of long-term exposure to a particular type of sound frequency or color light spectrum on the development of cancer in specific organs or tissues?

9. Do identical twins have a higher chance of developing the same type of cancer in comparison to non-identical twins due to their genetic similarities?

10. Can a person's particular artistic abilities, such as good drawing or painting skills, have an impact on their mental or emotional state in a way that causes a reduction in cancer risk or prognosis?

11. Can the rate at which age-related telomere shortening takes place have a direct effect on the risk of developing certain cancer types?

12. Is it possible that certain types of music or musical instruments could have a therapeutic effect by reducing stress and consequently benefiting cancer patients during their treatment or recovery?

13. Are there specific geographical regions in which a particular type of cancer is more prevalent due to the local climate, cuisine, or cultural practices? And, are there any such examples that are still not widely known in the medical community?

14. Is there a possibility of cancer cells interacting with one another and developing a form of "consciousness" or "collective intelligence" that could make them more adaptable and resistant to treatments?

15. How do medical advancements such as CRISPR technology or organoids grown in the lab potentially open new possibilities for personalized cancer treatment, and what are the main ethical concerns associated with these innovations?

conversation.content: summarise this: Three conclusions flow from this onomastic survey. First, names based on Hermanubis stand somewhat apart from other polytheophoric names common in the same period in Roman Egypt because, unlike the latter, they refer to a specific and independently attested god: a hybrid-named Hellenized version of Anubis. This is visible in the "onomastic behaviour" of Hermanubis names, such as their receptivity to various suffixes and their composition with names of other gods in "proper" polytheophoric formations. Second, the precise chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and the representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known conventionally as "Hermanubis" supports art historians' designation of the latter as "Hermanubis" (for which there is otherwise no positive support; see above). Finally, the connection of Hermanubis with Cynopolis evidenced by some of the personal names, and especially the connection with a priest of Anubis, suggests that Hermanubis continued to be closely associated with the traditional Anubis. It may not be warranted, therefore, to separate too forcefully, in the manner of Jean-Claude Grenier (1990: 265, 268), the more traditional funerary Anubis of the Isiac cult from a more "universalizing" Hermanubis.[22]

The onomastic survey reveals three conclusions: Hermanubis names are different from other polytheophoric names because they refer to a specific god; the overlap between onomastic evidence and representations of Hermanubis supports its designation as such; and Hermanubis is closely associated with the traditional Anubis and may not need to be separated from it.

conversation.content: summarise this: 	Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). Alexandria is the main cult center for the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, with archaeological evidence such as a dedication and a statuette found in the Serapeum precinct. The Cynopolite nome's connection to Hermanubis is more suggested by onomastic evidence, with one of the individuals named after him likely being a priest of Anubis and associated gods in the Cynopolite village of Laura. Some Alexandrian coins also depict the Cynopolite nome with an anthropomorphic Hermanubis on their reverse.

The Onomastic Evidence for the God Hermanubis

The Onomastic Evidence for the God Hermanubis
Amin Benaissa
Skip other details (including permanent urls, DOI, citation information)
Permalink: http://hdl.handle.net/2027/spo.7523866.0025.116
Permissions: This work is protected by copyright and may be linked to without seeking permission. Permission must be received for subsequent distribution in print or electronically. Please contact mpub-help@umich.edu for more information.
For more information, read Michigan Publishing's access and usage policy.
The personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and related forms are usually subsumed under the category of "polytheophoric" names characteristic of Roman Egypt. These are names that combine the names of two deities, such as Ἡρακλαπόλλων or Ἑρμαντίνοοϲ. They are attested solely in the Roman period, especially between the second and the fourth centuries, and were predominantly popular among males of the middle and upper classes in certain metropoleis like Hermopolis.[1] The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, however, though formally combining two divine names, is somewhat special: unlike other polytheophoric names, it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. In other words, it is the name of the god himself that is a "polytheophoric" formation, and this has some consequences on how the personal names based on this deity are formed. Before discussing these names, it is appropriate first to give a brief summary of our state of knowledge about Hermanubis. After reviewing the name forms based on this deity, the onomastic evidence will be related and compared to his iconographical and documentary attestations.
The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.
There are three forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt, in addition to two "proper" polytheophoric names. (In four instances [1, 5, 17, 21] the ending of the name is abbreviated or not preserved.) The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, attested six times (2, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15), simply replicates the god's name without further ado, through the phenomenon of "direct theonymy" (the giving to humans of unaltered divine names) that became widespread in the Roman period.[8] In an odd instance (9) the form Ἑρμανουβιϲ in the nominative is borne by a woman, an Alexandrian nurse (ἡ τροφόϲ).[9] It is highly unusual for female theophoric names to be unmarked for gender in this way.[10] I suspect that because the element -ανουβιϲ in Ἑρμάνουβιϲ was often declined with a dental declension in -ιδ-, it might have been conflated with the similar declension of Greek feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ.[11] If this is correct, it may be preferable to read the nurse's name as an oxytone (Ἑρμανουβίϲ). There are two further forms based on the god Hermanubis: Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (six instances: 3, 4, 7, 8, 12, 20) and Ἑρμανουβίων (four instances: 3, 6, 18, 19). -ᾶϲ and -ίων were, in fact, the commonest Greek suffixes for personal names based on the Egyptian god Ἄνουβιϲ.[12] It is interesting that in a business letter (3) the two forms Ἑρμανουβίων (l.38) and Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (l.41) are used interchangeably to designate the same individual. In this case, Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ is probably a hypocoristic of Ἑρμανουβίων, since the suffix -ᾶϲ often served this purpose.[13]
These forms of the name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ with modified suffixes already separate names based on Hermanubis from other polytheophoric names, which usually simply join two divine names without modifying the original suffix.[14] Indeed, because Hermanubis was conceptualized as a single god, it is not surprising to find personal names such as Ἑρμανοβάμμων (16) and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ (10), in which the name of Hermanubis is joined to that of other gods in the characteristic pattern of polytheophoric names. It is misleading to analyze these names as triple theophoric names, for they imply the juxtaposition of only two gods, Hermanubis and Ammon in one, and Hermanubis and Heracles in the other.[15] In this respect, they are not exceptions to the rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.
The near majority of the names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri of the second and third centuries AD. Possibly the earliest example is on an ostracon dated to AD 94 (1), but the name there is abbreviated and Ἑρμανο(υβίου) is Wilcken's resolution.[16] Otherwise, the next attestations are from the second quarter of the second century. There are overall eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. One instance is from an inscription dated broadly to the "imperial period." The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. What is notable about this chronological distribution is that it corresponds neatly to that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known conventionally as "Hermanubis." For example, the great number of Alexandrian coins that show a representation of this type on the reverse range from the reign of Trajan (or possibly as early as Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period. Likewise, the statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs of this god have all been assigned to the second or third century AD.[17]
Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). One of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple (LIMC nos. 5a, b), which suggests the existence of such an edifice in the city, probably in the Serapeum precinct given the provenance of the just-mentioned dedication and statuette from there and the frequent iconographical associations between "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in Alexandrian coins.[20] Alexandria, then, clearly emerges as the cult center and probably the birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consonant with the three Alexandrians bearing his name (5, 6, 9).[21] For the Cynopolite nome, the chief centre of the Egyptian god Anubis, the onomastic evidence is more suggestive than the archaeological and the iconographical. Among the three individuals with a name based on Hermanubis (11, 15, 16), there stands out the father of an underage priest of "Anubis, Leto and associated gods" in the Cynopolite village of Laura (15). Since priesthood was usually hereditary, the father Hermanubis was probably himself a priest of these gods. This onomastic connection of Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome also has an echo in the iconography: one or two Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse (LIMC nos. 3, 22).
Three conclusions flow from this onomastic survey. First, names based on Hermanubis stand somewhat apart from other polytheophoric names common in the same period in Roman Egypt because, unlike the latter, they refer to a specific and independently attested god: a hybrid-named Hellenized version of Anubis. This is visible in the "onomastic behaviour" of Hermanubis names, such as their receptivity to various suffixes and their composition with names of other gods in "proper" polytheophoric formations. Second, the precise chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and the representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known conventionally as "Hermanubis" supports art historians' designation of the latter as "Hermanubis" (for which there is otherwise no positive support; see above). Finally, the connection of Hermanubis with Cynopolis evidenced by some of the personal names, and especially the connection with a priest of Anubis, suggests that Hermanubis continued to be closely associated with the traditional Anubis. It may not be warranted, therefore, to separate too forcefully, in the manner of Jean-Claude Grenier (1990: 265, 268), the more traditional funerary Anubis of the Isiac cult from a more "universalizing" Hermanubis.[22]
I conclude by noting that a name based on Hermanubis is attested once outside Egypt in an inscription from Dion in Macedonia dated to the imperial period (22). The form of the name there is Ἑρμα-νούβιοϲ, which is not known from Egypt. The name is probably to be related to the cult of Hermanubis attested by a third-century dedication in Thessalonike (across the Thermaic golf from Dion), which was set up by a cultic association of Hermanubis on behalf of certain individuals. This document and the personal name, along with a statue of the god from the Sarapeum of Carthage (LIMC n. 15), suggest that the cult of Hermanubis enjoyed some popularity outside its original home in the Roman period.[23]

XII 652.6, 19 Ἑρμανουβίων?; c. 312?20P.NYU II 32.18 (= ZPE 140 [2002] 143)ἙρμανουβᾶϲOxy.?; IVOstrakine (Sinai)21I.Herm. 42.3 Ἑρμανο̣[Herm.; Imp. periodHerm.?22SEG XXXIV 625.2ἙρμανούβιοϲMacedonia (Dion); Imp. period?Appendix 2: Two literary instances of the name HermanubisAs a complement to the onomastic survey above, two literary attestations of the name Hermanubis are worth signaling. The first is a passage from Greogry of Nazianzus' autobiography in iambic verse known as De vita sua.[24] The context is Maximus the Cynic's failed attempt to supplant him as bishop of Constantinople in 380. Before the fruitless coup, according to Gregory's account, Peter, bishop of Alexandria and a supporter of Maximus, instructed some Egyptian sailors in Constantinople to spy on Gregory and aid Maximus. Gregory names and lambastes them as follows (De vita sua 834–843, in Patrologia Graeca XXXVII, col. 1087):
Κατάϲκοποι μὲν πρῶτον, οὓϲ τῆϲ ἐκκρίτου
835γῆϲ Ἰϲραήλ ποτ᾿ ἐξέπεμψ᾿ ὁ γεννάδαϲ·
πλὴν οὐκ Ἰηϲοῦϲ οὐδὲ Χάλεβ οἱ ϲοφοί,
ἀλλ᾿ εἴ τιϲ ὕβριϲ ἐν νέοιϲ καὶ πρεϲβύταιϲ,
Ἄμμων, Ἀπάμμων, Ἁρποκρᾶϲ, Ϲτιππᾶϲ, Ῥόδων,
Ἄνουβιϲ, Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, Αἰγύπτου θεοί,
840πιθηκόμορφοι καὶ κυνώδειϲ δαίμονεϲ,
δύϲτηνα ναυταρίδια καὶ παράφθορα,
εὔωνα, μικροῦ κέρματοϲ πολλοὺϲ θεούϲ
ῥᾷϲτ᾿ ἂν προθέντα, εἴπερ ἦϲαν πλείονεϲ.
First of all came the spies, like those once sent forth
by the father of Israel, the chosen land –
although it was not those wise men Joshua and Caleb,
but rather all the most insolent of the young men and old,
Ammon, Apammon, Harpocras, Stippas, Rhodon,
Anubis, Hermanubis, the gods of Egypt,
ape-shaped and dog-like demons,
a despicable and corrupt crew,
easily bribed, men who for a small sum would readily
offer many gods for sale, if only there were more to offer.
(tr.
White 1996: 73–75)Paul Gallay suggests that the names in 838–839 are fictional and part of the satire: an opportunity to associate the Egyptians, and implicitly the Egyptian church, with their pagan past and its odious animal worship.[25] At any rate, most of the names, Ϲτιππᾶϲ and Ῥόδων excepted, are characteristically Egyptian.[26] The occurrence of Ἄνουβιϲ near Ἑρμάνουβιϲ suggests the near equivalence of the names. The adjective κυνώδειϲ in 840, however, need not imply that Hermanubis refers to the canine-headed god, since it could have been triggered only by the name Ἄνουβιϲ (πιθηκόμορφοι, at least, does not correlate with any of the theophoric names cited).
The other literary instance similarly exploits the name Hermanubis for satiric effect. This is a curious, though poorly executed, anonymous poem in the Greek Anthology (AP XI 360), a diatribe against some strategos:
Νῦν ὁ ϲτρατηγὸϲ Ἑρμανούβηϲ ἐγένετο
κύων ἀδελφοὺϲ ϲυλλαβὼν Ἑρμᾶϲ δύο
ἀϲημοκλέπταϲ ϲυνδεθένταϲ ϲχοινίῳ,
4ψυχροὺϲ ἀώρουϲ Ταρταρίουϲ τε δαίμοναϲ.
οὐκ οἶδα χῶρον τοῦ τρόπου κατήγορον·
τρόπον δὲ χώρου τὸν κατήγορον λέγω.
Now the strategos Hermanoubes has turned into a dog, having seized two fraternal Hermeses, stealers of treasures, bound with rope, cold daemons of Tartarus before their time. I don't know a place that betrays character; but I say character betrays the place.
The form Ἑρμανούβηϲ is not attested in documents. There is likewise no instance of Ἀνούβηϲ (but cf. the Copticized Πανούβηϲ in P.Erl. I 108.ii.50 [Theb.; IV]). It is attractive, therefore, to emend Ἑρμανούβηϲ to Ἑρμάνουβιϲ (the final syllable of the name, being in anceps position, could be either short or long). The implied context of the poem is obscure. There is some hesitation among translators whether Ἑρμανούβηϲ is the subject ("the general H. turned into a dog" [Budé]) or predicate ("the general [unnamed] turned into the dog H." [Loeb]) of ἐγένετο. But surely the satire would be more biting if the general was actually named Hermanoubes/Hermanubis: the poet then would be playing on the associations of his name with Anubis the dog on the one hand (κύων) and Hermes the thief on the other (Ἑρμᾶϲ ... ἀϲημοκλέπταϲ). Whether κύων is a general insult or connotes the protective duties of the strategos is unclear, and so is the nature of the implied relationship between the strategos and the two thievish Hermeses.
Notes See Benaissa 2009. Although it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in the earlier period. The most obvious is the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ (see Ajootian 1990), attested from the fourth century BC onwards, but his name implies the paradoxical union of two different gods (Hermes and Aphrodite) rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. A more apt parallel is provided by Ζηνοποϲειδῶν, an epiclesis of the Carian god Zeus Osogoa, who received the additional determination "Poseidon" as a result of his representation with features such as the trident (see Blümel 1987, 128). In Egyptian religion, the tendency to unite the names of two gods was long established and is well known (cf. Leclant 1975). A comparable form to Hermanubis from the Roman period is Ἡλιοϲέραπιϲ, which is not attested as a personal name (pace Hopfner 1946, 45). Schwartz 1947 also postulates a syncretic funerary god Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, but this is based purely on the iconographical evidence of some seals, without any support from textual sources (the personal name Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, two instances of which have emerged since Schwartz's thesis, could be simply an example of a polytheophoric name and need not imply the recognition of an actual god of that name). The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected by Grenier 1977, 53–59, 95–98. Bernand, Inscriptions métriques n. 73 (Abydos; I–II) = GVI 1090, should also be added, as the Κυλλήνιοϲ Ἑρμῆϲ (9) leading the deceased to serve Osiris of Abydos is implicitly conflated with Anubis (see Dunand 1975, 158). Kákosy 1990, 145 points to some pre-Ptolemaic Egyptian statuettes, in which the feet or teeth of Thoth are modeled as jackal heads, as evidence that the later rapprochement of Anubis and Hermes was based on the earlier assimilation of Thoth to Anubis; but although Thoth and Anubis were closely associated in funerary contexts, I am not persuaded that these statuettes "wollten sicher den synkretischen Gott Thoth-Anubis darstellen" or that they are relevant to the question of the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis. See Leclant 1981, 871, and the references in Grenier 1977, 137–138. In the amulet published in Bonner 1950, n. 36 (Plate II) = LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 19, Anubis is described as holding in his right hand "a tall scepter resembling a Roman military standard, with palm leaves at top, and two garlands, the lower with ties" (Bonner 1950, 259). But this looks to me like a version of the kerykeion-cum-palm known from a number of coins of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis; see Grenier 1990, 265, and cf. the coins under 8(a). Whether the appellation "Hermanubis" was given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features is uncertain; Apuleius, Met. XI 11, refers to the god attolens canis cernices arduas and laena caduceum gerens simply as "Anubis." LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 13, found in Carthage or Cherchel, is the only representation for which an Alexandrian origin has been postulated, but on no firm basis (see Picard 1956, 176–179, who assigns to it an Alexandrian provenance and a date in the third century BC on the basis of the floral decoration). See Grenier 1990. Cf. Leclant 1981, 873. On "direct theonymy" see Parker 2000, 57–8, with further bibliography. For the accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ (Preisigke and some editors), see Clarysse 1997, 180. While the letter was found in the Fayum, the sender is clearly writing from Alexandria; cf. Bagnall and Cribiore 2006, 389–390. For some observations on the marking of gender in Greek personal names, see Davies 2000, 20–21. Cf. Gignac, Grammar, II 55–57; Mayser, Grammatik, I.2 22–23. For masculine names in -ιϲ, -ιδοϲ/-ιοϲ and feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ, see Pape-Benseler, Wörterbuch der griechischen Eigennamen3, xviii-xix. See e.g. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 33–34; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 34–35. See e.g. the "index des suffixes" in Masson 1990, II 632–633 s.v. -ᾶϲ ("suffixe d'hypocoristique et de sobriquet masculin").
The only exceptions are two instances ending in -ηράκλειοϲ (Ἑρμηράκλειοϲ [SB VI 9396.3], Ϲαραποηράκλειοϲ [SB XXII 15632.1]) and one ending in -απολλώνιοϲ (Ἡρακλαπολλώνιοϲ [P.Leit. 11.1; see BL VIII, 168–169]).
The ending -άμμων was attached to the names of most deities that appear in theophoric names (see Dunand 1963), so that its union with Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is unlikely to have a specific significance. One may adduce some numismatic representations in which "Hermanubis" is shown with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon; see LIMC V s.v. Hermanubis nos. 10a, b. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more intriguing and difficult to account for. If the papyrus is from the Heracleopolite nome as the ed. princ. suggests with a question mark (no internal evidence confirms this), the name may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome (Heracles = Egyptian Harsenuphis) with Hermanubis, without necessarily implying an affinity between the two. For what it is worth, a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius (Milne, Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins 1678 [Plate II]) shows jugate busts of Heracles and "Hermanubis." For a representation of the dog-headed Anubis with a club, see LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 35. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not actually occur in Egyptian documents, though Ἀνούβιοϲ is occasionally attested. The Macedonian inscription discussed below (22) is the only instance of the form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ. See Grenier 1990. On this inscription see Fraser 1972, II 413–414 n. 576. For another inscription from Egypt mentioning Hermanubis, see SB I 238. Fraser 1972, I 269. It is not clear to me to which of the statuettes in LIMC this corresponds (n. 21?). On the associations of "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990, 268. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis attested in 13 (and possibly 14) may also originate from Alexandria. Cf. Plut., De Is. et Os. 375e: Ἄνουβιϲ ... ὅτε καὶ Ἑρμάνουβιϲ ὀνομάζεται, τὸ μὲν ὡϲ τοῖϲ ἄνω τὸ δ᾿ ὡϲ τοῖϲ κάτω προϲήκων. Addendum, January 2010: The female name

Hermanubis is a god in Graeco-Egyptian religion, the result of the blending of the Greek god Hermes and Egyptian god Anubis. This deity was primarily associated with the afterlife and has a dual role as a guide to the dead and embalmer. The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, though formally combining two divine names, refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. In iconographic representations, Hermanubis is portrayed either as a canine-headed figure holding a kerykeion (staff) or wearing winged sandals or as an anthropomorphic young god wearing a calathos headdress and flanked by a dog or a jackal. Hermanubis is associated with funerary rituals in Egyptian religion and represents a syncretism, or fusion, of Egyptian and Greek religious beliefs.

conversation.content: summarise this: Three conclusions flow from this onomastic survey. First, names based on Hermanubis stand somewhat apart from other polytheophoric names common in the same period in Roman Egypt because, unlike the latter, they refer to a specific and independently attested god: a hybrid-named Hellenized version of Anubis. This is visible in the "onomastic behaviour" of Hermanubis names, such as their receptivity to various suffixes and their composition with names of other gods in "proper" polytheophoric formations. Second, the precise chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and the representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known conventionally as "Hermanubis" supports art historians' designation of the latter as "Hermanubis" (for which there is otherwise no positive support; see above). Finally, the connection of Hermanubis with Cynopolis evidenced by some of the personal names, and especially the connection with a priest of Anubis, suggests that Hermanubis continued to be closely associated with the traditional Anubis. It may not be warranted, therefore, to separate too forcefully, in the manner of Jean-Claude Grenier (1990: 265, 268), the more traditional funerary Anubis of the Isiac cult from a more "universalizing" Hermanubis.[22]

This survey draws three conclusions about the use of the name Hermanubis in Roman Egypt. First, Hermanubis names refer to a specific god and behave differently from other similar names. Second, the evidence for these names overlaps with the depiction of an anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known as Hermanubis. Finally, some personal names suggest a continued connection between Hermanubis and the traditional god Anubis, which challenges the idea of separating the two.

conversation.content: summarise this: Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). One of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple (LIMC nos. 5a, b), which suggests the existence of such an edifice in the city, probably in the Serapeum precinct given the provenance of the just-mentioned dedication and statuette from there and the frequent iconographical associations between "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in Alexandrian coins.[20] Alexandria, then, clearly emerges as the cult center and probably the birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consonant with the three Alexandrians bearing his name (5, 6, 9).[21] For the Cynopolite nome, the chief centre of the Egyptian god Anubis, the onomastic evidence is more suggestive than the archaeological and the iconographical. Among the three individuals with a name based on Hermanubis (11, 15, 16), there stands out the father of an underage priest of "Anubis, Leto and associated gods" in the Cynopolite village of Laura (15). Since priesthood was usually hereditary, the father Hermanubis was probably himself a priest of these gods. This onomastic connection of Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome also has an echo in the iconography: one or two Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse (LIMC nos. 3, 22).

The god Hermanubis is attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but most individuals named after him originate from Alexandrian or Cynopolite areas. Alexandria is likely the birthplace and cult center of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, and there is evidence of a temple dedicated to him in the Serapeum precinct. In the Cynopolite nome, there is a suggestive onomastic connection between Hermanubis and the father of an underage priest. Iconography also associates Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome on some Alexandrian coins.

conversation.content: summarise this: 	The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.

The divine name "Hermanubis" was created by assimilating the Egyptian god Anubis with the Greek god Hermes. This resulted in widespread artistic representations of a canine-headed Anubis with attributes of Hermes. In Roman Alexandria, a new iconographical type emerged featuring a fully anthropomorphic young god holding the same attributes as Anubis and wearing the calathos headdress. This type is conventionally labeled “Hermanubis," but none of the numerous representations of this type bear a legend or inscription identifying it as such. The name "Hermanubis" is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly from the Roman period.

conversation.content: summarise this: 	Notes See Benaissa 2009. Although it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in the earlier period. The most obvious is the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ (see Ajootian 1990), attested from the fourth century BC onwards, but his name implies the paradoxical union of two different gods (Hermes and Aphrodite) rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. A more apt parallel is provided by Ζηνοποϲειδῶν, an epiclesis of the Carian god Zeus Osogoa, who received the additional determination "Poseidon" as a result of his representation with features such as the trident (see Blümel 1987, 128). In Egyptian religion, the tendency to unite the names of two gods was long established and is well known (cf. Leclant 1975). A comparable form to Hermanubis from the Roman period is Ἡλιοϲέραπιϲ, which is not attested as a personal name (pace Hopfner 1946, 45). Schwartz 1947 also postulates a syncretic funerary god Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, but this is based purely on the iconographical evidence of some seals, without any support from textual sources (the personal name Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, two instances of which have emerged since Schwartz's thesis, could be simply an example of a polytheophoric name and need not imply the recognition of an actual god of that name). The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected by Grenier 1977, 53–59, 95–98. Bernand, Inscriptions métriques n. 73 (Abydos; I–II) = GVI 1090, should also be added, as the Κυλλήνιοϲ Ἑρμῆϲ (9) leading the deceased to serve Osiris of Abydos is implicitly conflated with Anubis (see Dunand 1975, 158). Kákosy 1990, 145 points to some pre-Ptolemaic Egyptian statuettes, in which the feet or teeth of Thoth are modeled as jackal heads, as evidence that the later rapprochement of Anubis and Hermes was based on the earlier assimilation of Thoth to Anubis; but although Thoth and Anubis were closely associated in funerary contexts, I am not persuaded that these statuettes "wollten sicher den synkretischen Gott Thoth-Anubis darstellen" or that they are relevant to the question of the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis. See Leclant 1981, 871, and the references in Grenier 1977, 137–138. In the amulet published in Bonner 1950, n. 36 (Plate II) = LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 19, Anubis is described as holding in his right hand "a tall scepter resembling a Roman military standard, with palm leaves at top, and two garlands, the lower with ties" (Bonner 1950, 259). But this looks to me like a version of the kerykeion-cum-palm known from a number of coins of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis; see Grenier 1990, 265, and cf. the coins under 8(a). Whether the appellation "Hermanubis" was given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features is uncertain; Apuleius, Met. XI 11, refers to the god attolens canis cernices arduas and laena caduceum gerens simply as "Anubis." LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 13, found in Carthage or Cherchel, is the only representation for which an Alexandrian origin has been postulated, but on no firm basis (see Picard 1956, 176–179, who assigns to it an Alexandrian provenance and a date in the third century BC on the basis of the floral decoration). See Grenier 1990. Cf. Leclant 1981, 873. On "direct theonymy" see Parker 2000, 57–8, with further bibliography. For the accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ (Preisigke and some editors), see Clarysse 1997, 180. While the letter was found in the Fayum, the sender is clearly writing from Alexandria; cf. Bagnall and Cribiore 2006, 389–390. For some observations on the marking of gender in Greek personal names, see Davies 2000, 20–21. Cf. Gignac, Grammar, II 55–57; Mayser, Grammatik, I.2 22–23. For masculine names in -ιϲ, -ιδοϲ/-ιοϲ and feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ, see Pape-Benseler, Wörterbuch der griechischen Eigennamen3, xviii-xix. See e.g. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 33–34; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 34–35. See e.g. the "index des suffixes" in Masson 1990, II 632–633 s.v. -ᾶϲ ("suffixe d'hypocoristique et de sobriquet masculin").

The article discusses the origins of the deity Hermanubis, a combination of the Egyptian god Anubis and the Greek god Hermes. While combining the names of two gods was not common in traditional Greek religion, it has some formal parallels in earlier periods. The article also mentions other syncretic gods, such as Zeus Osogoa and Helios-erapis, and discusses the literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes. The article also explores the origin of the name Hermanubis, including questions about its accentuation and the use of suffixes in Greek personal names.

conversation.content: summarise this: 	The ending -άμμων was attached to the names of most deities that appear in theophoric names (see Dunand 1963), so that its union with Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is unlikely to have a specific significance. One may adduce some numismatic representations in which "Hermanubis" is shown with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon; see LIMC V s.v. Hermanubis nos. 10a, b. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more intriguing and difficult to account for. If the papyrus is from the Heracleopolite nome as the ed. princ. suggests with a question mark (no internal evidence confirms this), the name may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome (Heracles = Egyptian Harsenuphis) with Hermanubis, without necessarily implying an affinity between the two. For what it is worth, a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius (Milne, Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins 1678 [Plate II]) shows jugate busts of Heracles and "Hermanubis." For a representation of the dog-headed Anubis with a club, see LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 35. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not actually occur in Egyptian documents, though Ἀνούβιοϲ is occasionally attested. The Macedonian inscription discussed below (22) is the only instance of the form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ. See Grenier 1990. On this inscription see Fraser 1972, II 413–414 n. 576. For another inscription from Egypt mentioning Hermanubis, see SB I 238. Fraser 1972, I 269. It is not clear to me to which of the statuettes in LIMC this corresponds (n. 21?). On the associations of "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990, 268. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis attested in 13 (and possibly 14) may also originate from Alexandria. Cf. Plut., De Is. et Os. 375e: Ἄνουβιϲ ... ὅτε καὶ Ἑρμάνουβιϲ ὀνομάζεται, τὸ μὲν ὡϲ τοῖϲ ἄνω τὸ δ᾿ ὡϲ τοῖϲ κάτω προϲήκων. Addendum, January 2010: The female name Ἑρμανουβίαινα (referring to an ἀϲτή, i.e. a citizen of Alexandria or one of the three Greek cities of Egypt) is now attested in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3 (17 March 291), published by L.H. Blumell, ZPE 165 (2008) 186–190. I have not been able to consult D. Stefanovic, "The Iconography of Hermanubis," in H. Györy (ed.), Aegyptus et Pannonia III. Acta Symposii anno 2004 (Budapest 2006) 271–276. For a recent text and translation of this work, see Lukinovich and Martingay 1997. Ch. Jungck's edition with commentary (Diss. Basel 1974) was not available to me.

The suffix -άμμων was commonly added to the names of deities in theophoric names, so the addition of this suffix to Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is not significant. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more difficult to explain, but it may simply be a combination of the chief god of a region (Heracles) with Hermanubis. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ is not found in Egyptian documents, but has been found in a Macedonian inscription. "Hermanubis" is often associated with Sarapis in iconography. There is also mention of an acting epistrategus Hermanubis from Alexandria. Additionally, a female name Ἑρμανουβίαινα has been found in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3.

conversation.content: summarise this: Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). One of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple (LIMC nos. 5a, b), which suggests the existence of such an edifice in the city, probably in the Serapeum precinct given the provenance of the just-mentioned dedication and statuette from there and the frequent iconographical associations between "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in Alexandrian coins.[20] Alexandria, then, clearly emerges as the cult center and probably the birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consonant with the three Alexandrians bearing his name (5, 6, 9).[21] For the Cynopolite nome, the chief centre of the Egyptian god Anubis, the onomastic evidence is more suggestive than the archaeological and the iconographical. Among the three individuals with a name based on Hermanubis (11, 15, 16), there stands out the father of an underage priest of "Anubis, Leto and associated gods" in the Cynopolite village of Laura (15). Since priesthood was usually hereditary, the father Hermanubis was probably himself a priest of these gods. This onomastic connection of Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome also has an echo in the iconography: one or two Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse (LIMC nos. 3, 22).

The Egyptian god Hermanubis was worshipped in various regions of Egypt, but most individuals with names based on him were from either Alexandria or the Cynopolite nome. Alexandria was likely the birthplace and cult center of the anthropomorphic Hermanubis, as evidenced by inscriptions and statues found there. In the Cynopolite nome, the onomastic evidence suggests a connection between Hermanubis and the god Anubis, possibly through priesthood. Iconography also depicts the Cynopolite nome personified by Hermanubis on some Alexandrian coins.

conversation.content: summarise this: The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.

The name "Hermanubis" refers to the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in various sources. The name is mostly known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources from the Roman period. The assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, but in Roman Alexandria, there emerged a new type where a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis. This type has been traditionally labeled "Hermanubis," but it is only a hypothetical convention as none of the numerous representations of this type bear a legend or inscription identifying it as such.

The first is a passage from Greogry of Nazianzus' autobiography in iambic verse known as De vita sua.[24] The context is Maximus the Cynic's failed attempt to supplant him as bishop of Constantinople in 380. Before the fruitless coup, according to Gregory's account, Peter, bishop of Alexandria and a supporter of Maximus, instructed some Egyptian sailors in Constantinople to spy on Gregory and aid Maximus. Gregory names and lambastes them as follows (De vita sua 834–843, in Patrologia Graeca XXXVII, col. 1087):

The text lists various ancient documents and inscriptions that mention the name "Hermanubis," a syncretic deity combining elements of the Egyptian god Anubis and the Greek god Hermes. The two literary attestations of the name come from Gregory of Nazianzus' autobiography, in which he criticizes Egyptian sailors who supported his opponent, and from a work by the fourth-century Christian writer Epiphanius the Latin, who connects the name Hermanubis with the Gnostics.

The article discusses the origin and significance of Hermanubis, a god in ancient Greek and Egyptian religion. It notes that while it was not common to combine the names of two gods in Greek religion, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in earlier periods. The article also examines the syncretism of Anubis and Hermes, two gods associated with death and transitions, and how their assimilation led to the creation of Hermanubis. The article provides insights from various sources, including literary and epigraphic sources, Egyptian statuettes, and ancient coins. It also discusses the marking of gender in Greek personal names and provides examples.
